title: Pediatric Mixed Hearing Loss Post-URI
chief_complaint: My hearing has gotten worse recently and my hearing aids aren't helping as much. My ears feel plugged.

problem_summary.course: Stable chronic loss with sudden decline following a cold.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Recent bad cold, sensation of plugged ears.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Hearing aids are currently ineffective; mother is concerned.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Restore hearing to baseline; improve hearing aid benefit.

history.present_illness: Patient brought in by mother due to increased concerns. Patient reports hearing has worsened recently and ears feel 'plugged' following a bad cold.
history.otologic_history: Bilateral, mild to moderate, sloping sensorineural hearing loss since birth.
history.prior_management: Has been doing quite well with binaural hearing aids; good student.
history.patient_goals: Determine cause of recent change and improve hearing.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral mixed hearing loss. Bone conduction thresholds reveal the underlying mild-to-moderate sloping SNHL (approx 30-55 dB HL). Air conduction thresholds are moderately-severe to severe (approx 60-75 dB HL), indicating a significant conductive component (Air-Bone Gap ~30-35 dB).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Word recognition scores obtained at high presentation levels (100 dB HL) due to mixed loss.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral Type B (flat) tympanograms with no measurable peak pressure or compliance, consistent with middle ear effusion.

tests.name: Wideband Acoustic Immittance (Reflectance)
tests.key_findings: High reflectance (near 100%) across low to mid frequencies for both ears, consistent with a stiff, mass-dominated system (fluid).

overall_audiologic_summary: The evaluation reveals a bilateral mixed hearing loss. The underlying sensorineural component remains consistent with the history of mild-to-moderate loss, but there is now a significant superimposed conductive component (air-bone gap ~30-35 dB). Tympanometry is flat (Type B) bilaterally and reflectance is high, strongly suggesting bilateral otitis media with effusion (middle ear fluid) following the recent cold.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows that while your permanent 'nerve' hearing is stable, you have a temporary blockage causing the recent drop in hearing.
The flat lines on the pressure test confirm there is likely fluid behind your eardrums, which fits with your recent cold and the 'plugged' feeling.
This fluid acts like an earplug, which is why your hearing aids aren't helping as much as usual right now.
We recommend seeing a physician or ENT to manage the fluid. Once the fluid clears, we expect your hearing to return to its previous levels.
notes_for_actor: Portray a child who is generally cooperative but frustrated that he can't hear well even with his devices.
The mother should be concerned that the hearing loss has progressed permanently, needing reassurance that this is likely a temporary medical issue on top of the permanent loss.
